That wasn't the point. The point was that the covariance structure was not replicated exactly with the eigenvalue/eigenvector decomposition.  The error was due to the decimals after the 16th place being truncated.  As soon as the programmer changed the variable definitions to floating, the problem disappeared.

I haven't seen anything that addresses this material directly, but this is a decent resource: Financial Risk Management: A Practitioner's Guide to Managing Market and Credit Risk 2nd Edition by Steve L. Allen   by Steve L. Allen (Author)
@kennethabbott8248  thanks
No.  Leptokurtosis implies a higher probability of larger losses.

​ @kennethabbott8248  Doesn't that depend on how the fat tailed distribution look?  The probability for a extremely large loss are indeed higher in a fat tailed distribution. But it can still be more likely for a 2,33 sigma loss in a normal.   For example, 2 distributions, one normal and one fat tailed with the same mean and variance. Both have 1000 observations. In the normal it will be approx 10 events outside 2,33 sigma, but in the fat tailed it can in the extreme case be 1. If that observation is far enough out in the tail, like 15-20 sigma, then the distributions can still have the same variance. Thus the probability of a 2,33 sigma loss is smaller in the fat tailed. Or am I missing something?

@moosecapital8886  Technically, of course, you are correct.  The fact that the two cumulative distribution functions cross each other demands that they cross a second time since both of the associated density functions must integrate out to 1.0.  In practice, in a diversified portfolio, the VaR at 99% and 95% are always higher for HS than for VCV or MC. (At least I have never seen any instances of an empirical VaR at these levels be less that that implied by the normal.)  Ive seen the crossover between 80% and 95%, typically around 90%.  My $0.02.
@kennethabbott8248  That makes sense, thanks a lot for the reply Kenneth. Really enjoyed the lecture

@Ken Abbott lol yeah totally understood!  The proof is easy and will be leave as an exercise, said by professor

Money held in a bank account and would likely be treated as cash and have no market risk associated it.  This is because absent a debasement there is no probability it loses value.  It would probably be insured via deposit insurance also.  This is where an assessment of credit risk would be more appropriate.  Credit risk measures, however, are usually applied over much longer time frames than the 1-10 day market risk measures.  The first places I would look to here would be credit transition matrices to guess probability of default by credit rating and sovereign CDS spreads to estimate the probability of a government not living up to its deposit insurance commitments.  Both are likely to reflect very small amounts of risk. - KA

@kennethabbott8248  Thanks Kenneth for your insights here. I did perform those metrics and performed a full assessment to the bank and it look likes financially sound. Now, by your opinion, how can I create a formula/var calculation to estimate the maximum amount of money a company can deposit into the account to be considered safe?
@BrigataUPG  Depending on the country, I'd simply use the deposit insurance limit, and adjust the risk by the PD of the sovereign providing the deposit insurance
@kennethabbott8248  thanks kenneth  This is what I need to figure out if the company might deposit 10mo instead of 5 for example

@kennethabbott8248  Hi Kenneth. In uk the business accounts are insured for max 85K. This is nothing for companies depositing millions. How would you act in this case? I'm not sure the deposit insurance might be considered as parameter here. Maybe assessing the financial soundness of the Bank itself included PD? even in this case I cannot identify a risk matrix to say 5 millions are safest than 15

@BrigataUPG  This is credit risk, pure and simple.  You’d need to calculate the probability of default from the bank’s CDS spread (or credit rating) and then study similar loss-given-default statistics for similar institutions. Generally, bank deposits are seen as very safe and attract very little capital.

@kennethabbott8248  yes agree but for my case study we are talking of a payment institution which use the bank account to money in and out their clients. This means there are million kept in the bank account and I'm not able to figure out what a max exposure would be in this specific case
@Ken Abbott Wow! I really didn't expect the explanation from the lecturer! Thank you so much!

Remember VaR always assumes stationarity. For yields, use % change (or log change) and apply that to the most recent yield you have: position * PV01 * close * s * 2.33 *100, where s is the stdev of the yield changes.
@kennethabbott8248  thank you so much for your answer! Really. I was referring to the units. I’ve read that, as PV01 is in dollars i have to re express the covariance matrix in bps.

@lautaropintos1  The covariance is always that of the returns (% changes or log changes).  You make the units adjustment in the position vector X, where the variance formula is X'VX and V is the covariance matrix.  BTW: very few people use this approach any more.  Most banks (~86%) use Historical Simulation.
@kennethabbott8248  thank you so much!! I’ll think about it 😊

You are correct That is a known weakness and the reason most forms don't use MC for VaR.  You can use a t-copula or make ex-post adjustments to calibrate the distribution.  A gaussian copula makes more sense in doing Vasicek-type default models and counterparty risk.
